I want you to think back it to March
first – does it feel like five weeks ago

or five years ago? The time before
coronavirus (let's call it BC) feels like
a distant memory. Time it seems messed up. Every day feels the same...

Every morning I sit down and open up the
ghost of my calendar and inbox. I click. I

scroll. I read. And after about 25 seconds
I wonder... what will I eat for lunch today?

I stand. I walk. I graze. And then I scroll
through news headlines and Instagram

photos for an absurd a period of time.
Wait what time is it? Sometimes time

flies and other times it drags on. But
it's not just you. There's actually a gap

between how objective, physical time
passes and how we experience it.
People often speak about time slowing down before a life-threatening event, like

remembering every single detail before a
car crash or a fall. So this was tested

in a 2007 study where researchers had
participants all from a tower. They free

fell, dropped 31 meters before they
were caught in a safety net. You can file

this one under completely ridiculous
science experiments that we're gonna

talk about anyway because it's
fascinating. Researchers found that this

scary situation influenced how the
participants perceived time. People

experience their own fall is lasting for
a lot longer than the fall that they

watched other people experience. But
researchers being researchers wanted to

find out why this was – did time seem to
slow down because our brain started

processing information faster and we
took a lot more in, or was our memory of

the event distorted? So the participants
were given this specially designed watch
it had these numbers on it that flashed at a fast rate so they could see if the

participants could read those numbers
when they were falling better than when

they were just on the ground. They called
it a chronometer which

just a fun word to say... chronometer. This
whole situation the tower and the drop

and the 31 meter fall and the
chronometer on their wrist with all of

the fast flickering numbers is just... a
lot. What the researchers found was that

this experience of time slowing down was
not because our brain sped up and could

press us all of this information faster –
people couldn't read those numbers any

better when they were falling than if
they were just standing on the ground

with the rest of us. Time warping is
actually an illusion caused by our
memories. This could happen because when you're frightened that your amygdala

gets involved in your memories. It
influences how you form memories which

leads to denser richer memories that
have a lot more information. Then when

you're recalling the event you interpret
it to take longer because you're

recalling more memories and when you
piece them all together you think that

the event has taken place over a longer
span of time. But... it's an illusion.

So it's emotions but actually play a role
in how we experience time passing. And

you don't have to be in immediate
physical danger to experience this. We've

seen this play out as well when people
are watching movies – scary movies. Another

study found that people's
judgement of time was distorted after

watching clips from scary movies like
The Shining compared to what were called

neutral clips like the daily weather
update. So what does all of this

free-falling drops and clips from The
Shining have to do with what we're

experiencing right now? Well there's a
couple of factors that I have written up

on my huge post-it notes. Post-it notes
are back. Well the first thing is that

it's unfamiliar – a lot of us haven't
experienced a situation like the one

we're in right now before so we see the
oddball effect come into play. This is

known for a study where people saw the
same circle come up on screen over and

over again and then when they saw a
different circle (quite literally the

oddball) they estimated that it was on
the screen for a longer period of time.

You're probably more familiar with this
in everyday contexts, like if you drive

to a new place it seems to take longer
than if you drive

somewhere that you're already familiar
with. The next thing is that the

situation we're in right now is scary –
it's stressful and people have a lot of

fear so if your memories of the past
month are more emotional it could feel

like more time has passed than it
actually has.

The next thing is that it's ongoing, the
situation we're in keeps changing and

this change happened really quickly in
March so we're constantly experiencing

new emotions, new news, the situation is
really novel so we're feeling these

things over and over again. But this
video isn't all doom and gloom! Because

there are some steps that you can take
to make time feel like it's flying.

You've probably heard people talk about
being in the zone or this state of flow
Which is where an enjoyable experience distorts your sense of time, you become

immersed in an activity so it feels like
time is passing more quickly. So great

activities to do this include playing an
instrument, running, knitting, dancing,

drawing – the takeaway message here is
that you could dance for the next two

months and Quarantine will be over.
Playing video games is an excellent one,

actually Luigi's Mansion has just melted
the hours away.
And you can try to take control,

you can take control of your own
time by setting the goals you can do

free online courses, watch educational
YouTube videos – you're off to a great

start – it could be helpful like that but
it doesn't have to be a lofty goal.

Personally I've been trying to cook eggs
better. Setting these small goals could

be helpful, but more so it takes your
mind off what's happening in the world

and even better can limit your exposure
to unnecessary coronavirus news. These
are all of my tips.
So many of us feel like we're in a coronavirus time warp

because of our emotional response and
the novelty and stress of the situation

make it feel like time that drags on.
When I think back to the first of March it

feels like forever ago. But we can
